I'm the world's most--
one of the reasons

167.88.text:
I've had such an odd career

170.18.text:
and down, is I'm

172.72.text:
And I can't really

174.72.text:
And actually the only
thing I've ever really put

177.40.text:
just total focus in was
"Trigger Happy," weirdly,

179.66.text:
and it was kind of when
there was no pressure.

182.02.text:
I didn't know "Trigger
Happy" was going to be huge.

184.14.text:
It was the first
comedy show I'd done.

185.74.text:
It was literally
like I'd suddenly

187.37.text:
got in a situation where
me and my new best friend,

189.85.text:
Sam, who I made it with,
who I met in a bar, as I

193.03.text:
was telling my girlfriend
that I had the opportunity

195.20.text:
to make this show, but I
couldn't afford a cameraman.

197.82.text:
And literally Sam was the
barman, leaned over and goes,

201.12.text:
Nobody believes the story,
but that is how we met.

205.16.text:
thinking we're still excited
we're going to be on telly.

209.96.text:
We basically had
fun, all the things

211.64.text:
that afterwards came when
advertising agencies would

214.27.text:
ring us up and offer stupid
money if we did an ad

218.50.text:
And we'd nod going,
well, it's quite tricky.

220.33.text:
The "Trigger Happy" style
was just me making Sam laugh,

223.29.text:
and he'd shake the
camera, and that was it.

228.30.text:
is a pretty good
hidden camera show.

231.04.text:
But I think where it
really differentiated

232.81.text: was when we went into the edit.

234.55.text:
And I'm kind of a
frustrated musician.

238.18.text:
I was in a band, but sadly
have no musical talent.

240.41.text:
But I've always loved
loads and loads of music.

243.88.text:
It was never like thought
through like this.

245.71.text:
But when I go into
the edit, it just

247.47.text:
made sense to me to
put my favorite moments

250.51.text:
of my favorite
tracks over stuff.

253.36.text:
And I remember the first
time we gave something in.

255.48.text: It was the dogs, fighting dogs.

257.08.text:
We used to have two dogs that
used to beat each other up.

259.45.text:
Like a lot of other
things in "Trigger Happy,"

261.37.text: that started with a vague point.

263.40.text:
We used to walk
through-- around here,

265.02.text:
actually, because we were
based on Charing Cross Road.

267.49.text:
And it was when all the CCTV
cameras just started going up.

270.51.text:
And you used to see all

275.89.text:
So it just made us laugh to
have the idea of setting up

278.34.text:
two dogs, one tied to a chair,
and there's an execution scene.

282.57.text:
And we just love the idea
that somewhere in some bank

285.65.text:
someone's spooning through, it's
like, what the fuck was that?

289.18.text:
So they used to start on

291.65.text:
But after a moment we just
thought, it doesn't matter.

295.14.text:
And the first time
we gave it in,

296.51.text:
I had some weird U2
opera tune on it.

299.68.text:
It was all quite weird,
because you think,

302.37.text: But actually, it's just a dog.

303.92.text:
And someone at Channel
4 said, don't you

306.19.text:
think you should put
some cartoon music on it?

308.62.text:
And I was just like, oh my
god, you so don't get this.

311.18.text:
So to answer the
question a long way,

312.72.text:
yes, we spent a long
time in the edit.

314.80.text:
And I think a lot of
it was about the music.

318.88.text:
Music was incredibly
expensive to clear abroad.

321.60.text:
The only place that bought
the entire soundtrack

325.83.text:
And I didn't sell it
to America for ages,

327.74.text:
because if it went
to America, it

329.96.text:
had to go with a
terrible sound alike.

331.59.text:
So all these great songs I'd

335.15.text:

337.68.text:
And it was just

339.21.text: But in the end, I gave up.

340.49.text:
And it did get to

342.11.text:
So yeah, the edit was what

344.28.text:
And I think people don't
appreciate that, really,

346.42.text:
because I think
in a funny sense,

347.79.text:
if you took all the

349.47.text:

357.08.text:
But I think the music gave

was me trying to be a

people, sent the request.

Nothing came back,
nothing came back.

456.19.text:
Finally I rang up,
and they said, well,

So finally I ring

DOM JOLY: I think all

491.84.text:
all business in a funny way,

496.76.text:
I think when you have a
certain level of-- I don't

500.14.text: know how to explain it, really.

502.39.text:
The odd thing to me is when
"Trigger Happy" was unknown

504.68.text:
and it wasn't a hit at all, we
were totally left on our own.

507.92.text:
And I think certainly
in comedy, when

511.29.text:
people say, as they often do
on Twitter, "you're not funny,"

514.15.text:
I'm like, well, that's a
very subjective thing to say.

516.63.text:
Because if I find it
funny, then it is funny.

519.43.text:
It's just you don't
find it funny.

521.19.text:
But the one thing that
definitely isn't funny

523.14.text:
is if 10 people get together
and decide what's funny.

527.21.text:
You end up with the
equivalent of the Eurostar

530.44.text:
interior decoration where
someone just thought,

532.47.text:
you know what,
yellow and gray is

533.84.text:
going to offend the
least amount of people.

536.96.text:
So to me in comedy,
even if you're

538.57.text:
doing something that's literally
everyone saying is awful,

541.36.text:
if you find it funny,
that's all you can do.

543.19.text:
The moment you try and guess
what other people find funny

545.77.text:
or listen to a
committee, you're fucked.

548.12.text:
And the irony of telly is
that "Trigger Happy," no one

550.47.text:
knew who we were, so we
totally were left alone, even

554.46.text:
And then the moment it was a

561.78.text:
Because they want
to be part of it.

And it instantly

Literally, you're either a

633.02.text:
apart from me, and

MALE SPEAKER: How did you

And I think I only

646.04.text:
because it's not like

647.79.text:
Because I'm not
interested in fame.

649.25.text:
But I definitely want

654.17.text:
And weirdly, I just

655.83.text:
with Louis Theroux who kind

658.89.text:
He was getting big at the
same time as "Trigger Happy"

662.79.text: And he went off to LA.

And I never quite
understood why.

665.29.text:
And he said he went from making
these documentaries that he

668.97.text:
really enjoyed, and

670.74.text:

673.35.text:
The moment you kind of felt,

677.14.text:
And he said, suddenly
he went from making

678.74.text:
shows he was really
interested in

680.11.text:

683.36.text:
is he going to be

684.94.text:
Like, are you going

685.84.text:
And I suppose that's

687.99.text:
But it's deeply unpleasant.
because then you start, A,

690.68.text:

693.62.text:
And then in the end, you

696.56.text:

698.49.text:
or you completely toe the

701.04.text:
And I think I've

703.15.text:

nick most ideas

But then again, I think
